questions.text: Mechanism of action of inhibin? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Inhibits FSH

 

Inhibin is a hormone secreted by the granulosa cells in the ovaries. Its primary role is to provide negative feedback on the anterior pituitary gland to regulate the secretion of follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH).

 

Inhibin specifically inhibits the release of FSH. By doing this, it helps regulate the menstrual cycle and ensures that only one dominant follicle develops during each cycle. This inhibition is crucial for the proper functioning of the reproductive system.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Increases FSH secretion: This is incorrect because inhibin decreases the secretion of FSH.

 

Option C. Increased estradiol: While inhibin is produced by granulosa cells, which also produce estradiol, inhibin itself does not directly increase estradiol levels.

 

Option D. Inhibits estradiol: This is incorrect because inhibin does not inhibit estradiol; it primarily inhibits FSH.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Inhibin's primary mechanism of action is to inhibit the secretion of follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) from the anterior pituitary gland, providing negative feedback to regulate the menstrual cycle.

questions.text: A young girl presented with delayed puberty. On examination, secondary sexual characters were absent, the nipples were widely spaced, and she was short in height. The most likely karyotype would be? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 45XO

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical features described in the question are characteristic of Turner syndrome, which is caused by the presence of only one X chromosome (45XO karyotype). The key features of Turner syndrome include:

 

  • Delayed puberty and absence of secondary sexual characteristics: Due to ovarian dysgenesis or streak ovaries, which lead to primary ovarian insufficiency.
  • Short stature: Almost all girls with Turner syndrome are short.
  • Widely spaced nipples and shield-like chest: These are typical physical features of Turner syndrome.
  • Webbed neck (common feature).

 

Note - 46XXX: This karyotype, also known as triple X syndrome, typically presents with taller than average stature and normal sexual development, which does not match the described clinical features.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The karyotype 45XO is associated with Turner syndrome, which is characterized by delayed puberty, absence of secondary sexual characteristics, short stature, widely spaced nipples, and other distinctive physical features.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a contraindication to the procedure shown? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Primigravida

 

The procedure shown is an External Cephalic Version (ECV), a technique used to turn a breech fetus to a cephalic (head-down) position before labor to facilitate a vaginal delivery. While it is generally more challenging to perform ECV in primigravida (first-time pregnant women) due to a tenser abdominal wall, it is not a contraindication. The procedure can still be performed in primigravida with caution and proper monitoring.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Placenta previa: This is a definite contraindication to ECV because the placenta covers the cervix, preventing safe vaginal delivery. Attempting ECV in such cases could cause placental abruption or severe bleeding, necessitating a cesarean section regardless.

 

Option C. Multiple pregnancy: ECV is contraindicated in multiple pregnancies (twins or more) because manipulating one fetus could adversely affect the position of the other, making the procedure unsafe.

 

Option D. Ruptured membranes: When membranes are ruptured, there is a loss of amniotic fluid (liquor), which is necessary for the maneuverability of the fetus during ECV. Without sufficient amniotic fluid, the procedure is difficult, risky, and not feasible.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Primigravida is not a contraindication for ECV, though it may be technically more challenging compared to multiparous women. Key contraindications to ECV include placenta previa, multiple pregnancy, and ruptured membranes.

choices.text: Light microscopy shows effacement of podocytes

questions.text: A 10-year-old presents with edema and anasarca. A diagnosis of minimal change disease is made. Which of the following is true about this condition? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Good response to steroids

 

Minimal change disease (MCD) is a type of glomerulonephritis that typically affects children and is characterized by the presence of nephrotic syndrome. The following statement is true about this condition:

 

  • Good response to steroids: MCD is often considered to be the most steroid-responsive form of nephrotic syndrome. The vast majority of children with MCD respond well to treatment with corticosteroids, with complete remission of proteinuria and edema occurring in over 90% of cases. However, the response to steroids may be less predictable in adults with MCD.

 

Other Options :

 

Option A. Light microscopy shows effacement of podocytes: Electron microscopy shows nonspecific obliteration of epithelial foot processes (not light microscopy)

 

Option C. Most common in adults: it is common in pediatric age group, not adults

 

Option D. Non-selective proteinuria: the patient will have massive nephrotic range proteinuria.

 

The causes of MCD are mostly idiopathic. It is usually associated with Hodgkin's lymphoma (due to the increased production of cytokines), respiratory infections, prophylactic immunizations, eczema, and rhinitis.

 

 

Clinically, they mostly present with proteinuria. The child presents with a history of edema that is initially noted around the eyes and gradually progresses into generalized edema. Hypertension and hematuria are uncommon.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Minimal change disease (MCD) is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children and has a very good response to corticosteroid treatment, resulting in complete remission of proteinuria and edema in over 90% of cases.

questions.text: All of the following are contraceptive methods used post-coitus except? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Danazol

 

Explanation:

 

  • Post coitus contraception means emergency contraception
  • Danazol is an androgen similar to testosterone and is used in endometriosis and fibrocystic breast disease

 

Other Options:

 

Option B CuT200: CUT200 is an intrauterine contraceptive device which can be used in emergency contraception (up to 120 h/ 5 days post coitus)

 

Option C. RU486: RU486 is Mifepristone. This is an anti-progesterone and can be used for emergency contraception)

 

Option D. Combined high dose estrogen-progestin pills: Combined high dose OCPs – used as Yuzpe’s regime, is a method of post-coital/ emergency contraception 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The following can be used as emergency contraceptives:

 

 

Ref: Page no 630, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6th edition

questions.text: A patient is planned to undergo hysteroscopic polypectomy using bipolar electrocautery. What is the ideal agent for distention? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Normal saline

 

 Explanation:

 

  • In bipolar cautery, electricity has to be conducted from one electrode to the other. So normal saline is preferably used.
  • If a monopolar resectoscope is used, then a non-electrolyte solution like glycine is required.

 

Fluid media in Hysteroscopy:

 

The following distension media can be used in hysteroscopy

 

  • CO2: Good for diagnostic procedures but not for operative hysteroscopy
  • Normal Saline
    • Not to be used with monopolar electrocoagulation
    • Good for minor procedures using bipolar instruments/ office procedures as there is very less risk of electrolyte imbalance
  • Dextran 70
    • Useful in patients with bleeding as it does not mix with blood
    • Can cause anaphylaxis, electrolyte imbalance ans fluid overload
  • Low viscosity, nonconductive fluids like: 1.5% Glycine, 3% sorbitol and 5% mannitol
    • Used in operative hysteroscopy using monopolar resectoscopes
    • Safe as there is no electrolytes to disperse the current and impede the electrosurgical effect
    • Associated with electrolyte disturbances and fluid overload

 

Educational Objective:

 

Normal saline is the ideal distention medium for hysteroscopic procedures using bipolar electrocautery due to its suitability in conducting electricity between electrodes without causing significant electrolyte imbalance.

 

Ref: Page no 793, Novaks Gynecology 15th edition

questions.text: A patient present at 10 weeks pregnancy. She asks for medical method of abortion. What will you advise her? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mifepristone and misoprostol

 

The Ans. is Mifepristone and misoprostol. Medical termination of pregnancy (MTP) using mifepristone and misoprostol is recommended for up to 12 weeks of gestation as per the World Health Organization (WHO) guidelines.

 

 While the Government of India allows medical abortion up to 9 weeks, the WHO supports the use of this regimen until 12 weeks, though the likelihood of failure increases slightly as the gestational age advances. Mifepristone is an anti-progestin that primes the uterus, and misoprostol, a prostaglandin, induces uterine contractions to expel the pregnancy. This combination is effective and widely used in the first trimester and can also be employed in the second trimester with adjustments in misoprostol dosing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hyperosmolar saline: This is an outdated method and primarily used in the second trimester. It is not recommended for first-trimester abortions due to associated risks and inefficacy compared to current medical regimens.

 

Option C. Oxytocin: Oxytocin is primarily used to induce labor in the second or third trimester. It is not effective or commonly used for first-trimester medical abortions due to its different mechanism of action and limited efficacy in early gestation.

 

Option D. Dinoprostone: Dinoprostone is a prostaglandin used primarily for cervical ripening and labor induction in the third trimester. It is not suitable for first-trimester medical abortion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a medical abortion at 10 weeks, the recommended regimen is mifepristone followed by misoprostol, as it is effective and safe up to 12 weeks of gestation according to WHO guidelines.

questions.text: Identify the maternal condition that can lead to the findings in the baby as shown below? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pre-gestational diabetes

 

Explanation

 

The image shows a condition known as mermaid syndrome or sirenomelia, which is a rare congenital deformity characterized by the fusion of the lower limbs. This condition is characteristically associated with overt (pre-gestational) diabetes mellitus.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Sirenomelia (mermaid syndrome) is strongly linked to maternal pre-gestational diabetes.
  • Overt diabetes mellitus during pregnancy is known to cause various congenital anomalies, with cardiac anomalies being the most common, specifically ventricular septal defects (VSD).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Gestational diabetes mellitus: Gestational diabetes typically occurs later in pregnancy and does not usually cause congenital anomalies, as organogenesis is largely complete by the time gestational diabetes is diagnosed.

 

Option C. Effect of valproate: Valproate exposure during pregnancy is associated with neural tube defects, facial anomalies (such as cleft lip and palate), and cardiac anomalies, but not sirenomelia.

 

Option D. Hypertensive on ACE inhibitors: ACE inhibitors and angiotensin receptor blockers reduce fetal renal perfusion, leading to conditions such as oligohydramnios and subsequent pulmonary hypoplasia, but they do not cause sirenomelia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pre-gestational diabetes is associated with an increased risk of congenital anomalies, including mermaid syndrome (sirenomelia), characterized by the fusion of lower limbs.

 

Ref: Page 384, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text:
Which are the tumor markers for the ultrasound image shown below? (NEET PG 2024)

 

 

 

  1. CA 125
  2. LDH
  3. AFP
  4. hCG
  5. CA 19-9
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1,2,3,4,5


The ultrasound image shows an ovarian mass, and various tumor markers are used in the evaluation of ovarian tumors to help in diagnosis and management:

 

  1. CA 125: This is primarily used as a marker for epithelial ovarian cancer, especially serous cystadenocarcinoma. Elevated levels of CA 125 are often associated with advanced stages of the disease.
  2. LDH (Lactate Dehydrogenase): This marker is associated with dysgerminoma, a type of germ cell tumor of the ovary. Elevated LDH levels can suggest the presence of this tumor.
  3. AFP (Alpha-Fetoprotein): AFP is a marker used for yolk sac tumors, which are rare but aggressive ovarian germ cell tumors.
  4. hCG (Human Chorionic Gonadotropin): hCG is elevated in cases of non-gestational choriocarcinoma, which is another form of germ cell tumor.
  5. CA 19-9: This tumor marker is associated with mucinous cystadenocarcinoma, a type of ovarian epithelial tumor. It is also elevated in other gastrointestinal malignancies.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Different tumor markers, including CA 125, LDH, AFP, hCG, and CA 19-9, are utilized to assess ovarian masses and differentiate between various types of ovarian tumors.

questions.text: Conjunctival xerosis is associated with which vitamin deficiency? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vitamin A

 

Conjunctival xerosis, which refers to the drying and thickening of the conjunctiva, is indeed associated with Vitamin A deficiency. Vitamin A is crucial for maintaining the health of epithelial tissues, including those of the eye. This deficiency can lead to various ocular manifestations, including night blindness and xerophthalmia, of which conjunctival xerosis is a part.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin D: Vitamin D deficiency is primarily associated with conditions related to bone health, such as rickets in children and osteomalacia in adults. Conjunctival xerosis is not a recognized consequence of Vitamin D deficiency.

 

Option B. Vitamin K: Vitamin K deficiency is primarily associated with bleeding disorders due to impaired blood clotting. While Vitamin K deficiency can lead to bleeding in various tissues, conjunctival xerosis is not a recognized consequence of this deficiency.

 

Option C. Vitamin C: Vitamin C deficiency can lead to scurvy, which is characterized by symptoms such as bleeding gums, easy bruising, and impaired wound healing. However, conjunctival xerosis is not a typical manifestation of Vitamin C deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Conjunctival xerosis is specifically associated with Vitamin A deficiency and is a significant indicator of this deficiency, affecting the epithelial tissues of the eye.

choices.text: Isthmus because of more circular muscles than longitudinal muscles
Isthmus because of narrowest area
Ampulla because of more circular muscles than longitudinal muscles
Ampulla because of narrowest area

questions.text: The most common site of tubal ligation and the reason for ligation at this site is? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Isthmus because of narrowest area

 

The most common site for tubal ligation is the isthmus of the fallopian tube. The isthmus is the narrowest portion of the tube, which makes it an ideal site for ligation. One key reason for selecting this site is that it preserves the broader segments of the tube, such as the ampulla, which are essential if recanalization (reversal of the ligation) is needed later. By ligating the narrowest part, the wider and more functionally significant areas remain intact, facilitating easier and more successful surgical reanastomosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Isthmus because of more circular muscles than longitudinal muscles: This is incorrect because the reason for ligating at the isthmus is primarily its narrowness, not muscle structure.

 

Option C. Ampulla because of more circular muscles than longitudinal muscles: The ampulla is not the preferred site for ligation because it is wider and more functionally significant. Ligation here would complicate future recanalization procedures.

 

Option D. Ampulla because of narrowest area: This is incorrect because the ampulla is not the narrowest part of the fallopian tube; the isthmus is.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The isthmus is the most common site for tubal ligation due to its narrowness, which preserves the broader, more functional parts of the tube, making recanalization easier if needed in the future.

questions.text: A patient comes after 6 months of vaginal delivery with an episiotomy repair with pain at the site of episiotomy which increases during her periods. On palpation, a nodular lesion is felt. The probable diagnosis is? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Endometriosis

 

The patient presents with pain at the episiotomy site that worsens during her menstrual periods, along with a palpable nodular lesion. This is a classic presentation of scar endometriosis, a condition where endometrial tissue is implanted in the scar tissue of an episiotomy or caesarean section. The ectopic endometrial tissue responds to hormonal changes during the menstrual cycle, leading to cyclical pain, swelling, and sometimes bleeding at the site, which explains the patient's symptoms. Scar endometriosis often requires surgical excision for treatment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Retained suture: While retained sutures can cause pain, they do not cause cyclic pain associated with menstrual periods and typically do not present as a nodular lesion that grows or bleeds during menstruation.

 

Option C. Inclusion cyst: An inclusion cyst may form at the site of an episiotomy scar but would not be associated with cyclic pain or changes during the menstrual period. Inclusion cysts are usually painless unless infected.

 

Option D. Melanoma: Melanoma would not typically present with cyclic pain related to menstruation. It is usually a pigmented lesion that may change in size or color, rather than one that causes cyclic bleeding and pain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Scar endometriosis should be suspected when there is cyclic pain and a nodular lesion at the site of an episiotomy or surgical scar, especially if symptoms correlate with menstrual periods.

questions.text: A 22-year-old pregnant lady presents with fever and is put on antibiotics. Fever is still not brought under control. On further investigation, she is diagnosed to have septic pelvic thrombophlebitis. Which among the following is the next course of treatment for her? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Antibiotics + Heparin

 

Explanation:

 

Antibiotics + heparin:

 

Septic pelvic thrombophlebitis (SPT) is a rare postpartum infective complication characterized by persistent high-grade fever despite broad-spectrum antibiotic therapy. It typically occurs after delivery or abortion and is often seen in women with risk factors like cesarean section, prolonged labor, or pelvic infection.

 

The fever in SPT is caused by a septic thrombus in the pelvic veins—most commonly the ovarian vein—that harbors bacteria and incites a sustained inflammatory response. Since antibiotics alone cannot fully penetrate the infected thrombus, the addition of anticoagulation (usually low molecular weight heparin) is essential. Heparin helps in lysing the thrombus, preventing further propagation and improving antibiotic penetration.

 

Clinical improvement is usually seen within 48–72 hours of initiating combined therapy with antibiotics and heparin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stop antibiotics and start heparin:  Incorrect because infection is still present—antibiotics are needed to control the infective component.  Stopping antibiotics would worsen sepsis.

 

Option C. Surgical embolectomy:  Too invasive and not first-line.  Reserved for rare cases with septic emboli or failure to respond to medical management.

 

Option D. Hysterectomy: Not indicated unless there’s uncontrolled pelvic infection not responding to medical therapy or associated endomyometritis with uterine necrosis.  SPT is usually confined to pelvic veins, not requiring removal of the uterus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The best management for pregnant women with antiphospholipid syndrome (APS) to prevent recurrent pregnancy loss includes low-dose aspirin and low molecular weight heparin (LMWH).

 

Ref: Page no 2951, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: Cardiac oedema and neuropathy are seen in which of the following vitamin deficiencies? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Thiamine

 

Thiamine (Vitamin B1) deficiency is associated with cardiac edema and neuropathy. The deficiency of thiamine can manifest in two main forms:

 

  • Wet beriberi: This form of thiamine deficiency primarily affects the cardiovascular system. It is characterized by symptoms such as tachycardia, cardiomegaly, cardiac failure, and edema. This condition is commonly observed in populations with diets heavily based on polished rice, such as in refugee camps.
  • Dry beriberi: This form affects the nervous system and includes symptoms such as peripheral neuropathy, optic atrophy, ataxia, and irritability.

 

Thiamine deficiency can also lead to complications such as lactic acidosis and Wernicke encephalopathy in adults. The diagnosis can be established by assessing erythrocyte transketolase activity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Biotin: Biotin deficiency is rare and can be observed in individuals who consume large amounts of raw eggs (which contain avidin that binds biotin) for several months. Symptoms include anorexia, vomiting, dry scaly dermatitis, glossitis, and hypercholesterolemia. It can also occur in patients receiving long-term parenteral nutrition without biotin supplementation.

 

Option C. Pyridoxine (Vitamin B6): Deficiency in pyridoxine is associated with neonatal seizures and other symptoms such as dermatitis, glossitis, and depression, but not specifically with cardiac edema and neuropathy.

 

Option D. Riboflavin (Vitamin B2): Deficiency in riboflavin, known as ariboflavinosis, presents with photophobia, glossitis, angular stomatitis, seborrheic dermatitis, corneal vascularization, and cataracts, but not with cardiac edema and neuropathy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thiamine (Vitamin B1) deficiency is characterized by cardiac edema and neuropathy, manifesting as wet beriberi (cardiovascular symptoms) and dry beriberi (neurological symptoms).

questions.text: What is the type of pelvis shown below? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Gynecoid Pelvis

 

Explanation:

 

Given image shows a Gynecoid pelvis.

 

Based on the shape of the inlet female pelvis can be divided into 4 types: Gynecoid (50%) Android (25%) Anthropoid (20%) and platypelloid (5%) (Caldwell-Molloy anatomical classification)

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Gynecoid pelvis, which is slightly oval or round in the transverse axis, is the most common and ideal type for childbirth.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition page 403, William’s textbook of Obstetrics page 34

choices.text: Increased fluid intake
Small frequent meals

questions.text: Vomiting in pregnancy is managed by? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Small frequent meals

 

Vomiting in pregnancy, often referred to as morning sickness, can be managed by recommending small, frequent meals. This approach helps to stabilize blood sugar levels and reduces the likelihood of nausea. Eating small amounts of food more frequently can prevent the stomach from becoming too full or too empty, both of which can trigger nausea and vomiting.

 

DOC – Doxylamine combined with Pyridoxine (B6).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Domperidone: While domperidone is used for nausea and vomiting, it is not the drug of choice for managing vomiting in pregnancy. The preferred pharmacological treatment is a combination of doxylamine and pyridoxine.

 

Option B. Increased fluid intake: While staying hydrated is important, increasing fluid intake alone is not the primary management strategy for vomiting in pregnancy. It may be difficult for pregnant women experiencing severe nausea to tolerate large amounts of fluids.

 

Option D. MTP (Medical Termination of Pregnancy): This is not a management option for vomiting in pregnancy. MTP is a procedure for terminating a pregnancy and is unrelated to managing nausea and vomiting.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Managing vomiting in pregnancy is best achieved by advising small, frequent meals to help stabilize blood sugar levels and reduce nausea.

questions.text: Which among the following is the most common presentation of postpartum nerve injury? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Foot drop

 

Explanation:

 

The most common postpartum nerve injury is an injury to the peroneal nerve, which results in foot drop. This type of injury often occurs during deliveries where the lithotomy position is used for an extended period. The lithotomy position can cause prolonged pressure on the peroneal nerve, which is located near the fibular head, leading to nerve damage.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Peroneal nerve injury: The peroneal nerve is susceptible to compression, especially when the legs are positioned in stirrups for prolonged periods, as is common in the lithotomy position during childbirth.
  • Foot drop: This condition is characterized by an inability to dorsiflex the foot, leading to a dragging foot while walking.
  • Symptoms: Patients may present with weakness in lifting the front part of the foot and toes, a high-stepping gait to prevent the foot from dragging, and numbness or tingling over the top of the foot and the outer part of the upper leg.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Facial palsy: This is not commonly associated with postpartum nerve injuries.

 

Option B. Wrist drop: This condition results from a radial nerve injury and is not a common presentation of postpartum nerve injuries.

 

Option D. Claw hand: This is associated with ulnar nerve injury and is also not a common presentation of postpartum nerve injuries.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most common postpartum nerve injury is peroneal nerve injury, leading to foot drop, often associated with the lithotomy position used during childbirth.

choices.text: Placenta weight at term is 470 g
Extraplacental membranes and 2-vesseled umbilical cord present

questions.text: The following are correct regarding normal placenta, except: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Extraplacental membranes and 2-vesseled umbilical cord present

 

Explanation:


The statement in option C is incorrect regarding the normal placenta.

 

Extraplacental membranes and 2-vesseled umbilical cord present: In a normal placenta, the umbilical cord typically contains three vessels (two arteries and one vein), not two. The presence of extraplacental membranes (membranes extending beyond the placental margins) is not a feature of a normal placenta; it is rather an abnormal finding if present.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Placenta weight at term is 470 g: This is correct. The average weight of a term placenta is around 500 grams, but it can range from approximately 450 to 700 grams. The option provides a reasonable estimate.

 

Option B. Round-oval with 22 cm diameter: This is partially correct. The normal placenta is indeed round to oval, but the average diameter is about 15-20 cm, not 22 cm. The provided diameter exceeds the typical range.

 

Option D. Central thickness > 2.5 cm: This is correct. The normal thickness of the placenta at term is greater than 2.5 cm, commonly around 2.5 to 4 cm. A thickness greater than 2.5 cm falls within the normal range.

 

Educational Objective:


The normal placenta at term typically weighs around 500 grams, has a diameter of 15-20 cm, is 2.5 cm thick, and has a 3-vessel umbilical cord with a central insertion.

 

Ref: Page 245 Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: What is altered in thyroid profile throughout pregnancy? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Total T3 level

 

Explanation:

 

During pregnancy, the thyroid profile undergoes several changes due to physiological adaptations. One significant change is the increase in total T3 and T4 levels. This occurs because of the elevated levels of thyroid-binding globulin (TBG), which increases the amount of bound thyroid hormones. Despite this increase, the levels of free T3 and free T4 remain relatively unchanged.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Thyroid-binding globulin (TBG): The production of TBG increases during pregnancy due to elevated estrogen levels. This leads to higher levels of total T3 and total T4.
  • Free T3 and Free T4: Despite the increase in total hormone levels, the free (unbound) hormone levels remain relatively stable. This is why free T3 and free T4 are preferred for thyroid function testing during pregnancy.
  • TSH: The levels of TSH may decrease slightly in the first trimester due to the thyrotropic effects of hCG (human chorionic gonadotropin), but they generally stabilize in the second and third trimesters.
  • Iodine requirement: Pregnancy increases the body's requirement for iodine by about 50%, due to increased renal clearance and fetal iodine needs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Free T3 level: This remains relatively unchanged during pregnancy.

 

Option B. Free T4 level: This also remains relatively unchanged during pregnancy.

 

Option D. TSH level: While TSH levels can decrease slightly in the first trimester, they typically stabilize throughout the rest of the pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In pregnancy, total T3 and T4 levels increase due to elevated thyroid-binding globulin, while free T3 and T4 levels remain unchanged.

 

Ref: Page no 57, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 9th edition

questions.text: In screening for diabetes in pregnancy, the dose of oral glucose load given is? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 75g

 

Explanation:

 

For screening and diagnosis of gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM), the oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT) is commonly used. The standard protocol involves a 75-gram oral glucose load.

 

Protocol for 75-gram OGTT:

 

International Guidelines: According to the International Association of Diabetes in Pregnancy Study Groups (IADPSG):

 

  • The test is performed after an overnight fast.
  • A fasting blood sample is taken.
  • The woman is then given a 75-gram oral glucose load.
  • Blood samples are taken at 1 hour and 2 hours after the glucose load.
  • Diagnostic thresholds:
    • Fasting glucose ≥ 92 mg/dL
    • 1-hour glucose ≥ 180 mg/dL
    • 2-hour glucose ≥ 153 mg/dL

 

A diagnosis of GDM is made if any one of these values is met or exceeded.

 

DIPSI Criteria (India):

 

This method can be used irrespective of the prandial state (whether the woman is fasting or not).

 

  • A 75-gram oral glucose load is given.
  • A blood sample is taken 2 hours later.
  • A 2-hour plasma glucose value ≥ 140 mg/dL indicates GDM.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 50g: Used in the 50-gram glucose challenge test, which is a preliminary screening test, but not diagnostic.

 

Option C. 100g: Used in the 3-hour OGTT, which is less commonly used now compared to the 75-gram test.

 

Option D. 150g: Not used for GDM screening or diagnosis.

 

Educational objective:

 

The current standard for screening and diagnosing gestational diabetes mellitus is the 75-gram oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT).

questions.text: A multiparous woman from a low socio-economic status whose husband is a truck driver is to be screened for cervical cancer. What is the best way? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pap smear

 

Explanation:

 

Cervical cancer screening is crucial for early detection and prevention. The Pap smear (Papanicolaou test) is the standard screening test for cervical cancer, particularly in resource-limited settings. It involves collecting cells from the cervix to detect precancerous or cancerous changes.

 

Why Pap Smear?

 

  • Accessibility: It is widely available and can be performed in low-resource settings.
  • Cost-effective: It is a cost-effective method for cervical cancer screening.
  • Proven efficacy: It has been proven to significantly reduce the incidence and mortality of cervical cancer through early detection and treatment of precancerous lesions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CA125: This is a biomarker used in the screening and monitoring of ovarian cancer, not cervical cancer.

 

Option B. Laparoscopy: This is a surgical procedure used for diagnosis and treatment but not for routine screening.

 

Option C. TVS (Transvaginal Sonography): Primarily used for evaluating the uterus and ovaries, not suitable for cervical cancer screening.

 

Educational objective:

 

The Pap smear is the best and most widely recommended screening test for cervical cancer, especially in low socio-economic and resource-limited settings.

questions.text: Twin pregnancy where 1 twin is older by 1 month than the other on ultrasound. What is this known as? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Superfetation


Superfetation is the phenomenon where two ova are released in separate menstrual cycles and are fertilized at different times, leading to the conception of twins with different gestational ages. This means that one twin is conceived at a later date than the other, which can result in an observable difference in size or developmental stage on ultrasound. Although superfetation is documented in some animals, it is extremely rare and largely theoretical in humans due to the cessation of ovulation after the first conception. Nonetheless, it is the best explanation for the scenario where one twin appears to be older by a month than the other.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Superfecundation: Superfecundation occurs when two ova released in the same menstrual cycle are fertilized by separate acts of intercourse. The twins conceived have the same gestational age, although they may vary slightly in size. This phenomenon does not explain a one-month difference in age between twins.

 

Option C. Illegitimate: This term is not a medical explanation related to twin pregnancies. It refers to a non-scientific or socially defined concept and does not pertain to any biological condition involving twins.

 

Option D. Monochorionic monoamniotic: This refers to twins that share both the chorion and the amniotic sac, resulting from the splitting of a single fertilized egg. These twins are identical and have the same gestational age; they do not account for any significant size or age discrepancy.

 

Educational Objective:


Superfetation refers to a rare phenomenon where twins are conceived at different times, resulting in a significant difference in gestational ages, although it is mostly theoretical in humans.

questions.text:
Arrange the following in sequence? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. Crowning
  2. Engagement
  3. Restitution
  4. External rotation
questions.solution:
Ans. A) B, A, C, D

 

Explanation:

 

The sequence of cardinal movements in the mechanism of labor is a series of positions and motions that the fetus goes through as it navigates through the birth canal. These movements are:

 

  1. Engagement: This is when the fetal head enters the pelvic inlet and the widest part of the head has passed through the pelvic brim.
  2. Descent: The downward movement of the fetal head within the pelvic inlet.
  3. Flexion: The fetal head bends so the chin is brought closer to the chest, presenting the smallest diameter to the birth canal.
  4. Internal Rotation: The fetal head rotates to align with the maternal pelvis.
  5. Crowning: The fetal head is visible at the vulva without slipping back.
  6. Extension: The fetal head extends as it passes under the symphysis pubis.
  7. Restitution: The fetal head rotates to the position it was in when it engaged in the pelvis.
  8. External Rotation: The fetal shoulders rotate to align with the head.
  9. Expulsion of the rest of the body: The remainder of the fetal body is delivered.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. B, A, D, C: This sequence incorrectly places external rotation before restitution.

 

Option C. B, C, A, D: This sequence incorrectly places restitution before crowning.

 

Option D. B, D, A, C: This sequence incorrectly places external rotation before crowning and restitution.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The cardinal movements in the mechanism of labor occur in the following sequence: engagement, descent, flexion, internal rotation, extension (preceded by crowning), restitution, external rotation, and expulsion of the rest of the body.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8th edition pg 145

questions.text: A 21-year-old primigravida presents to the antenatal OPD. Her school going nephew who lives in the same house has contracted varicella. A blood sample is taken for Antibodies against varicella. The report is negative. What does this signify? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Susceptible to chicken pox

 

Explanation:

 

Chickenpox in Pregnancy:

 

  • Pregnant women with uncertain or no previous history of chickenpox, who have been exposed to the infection, should have a blood test to determine their immunity to Varicella-Zoster Virus (VZV).
  • A negative antibody test indicates that the woman is not immune to VZV and is susceptible to chickenpox.
  • If a pregnant woman is not immune and has had significant exposure, she is at risk of developing chickenpox and should be administered varicella-zoster immunoglobulin (VZIG).
  • VZIG is effective up to 10 days after contact.
  • Symptomatic treatment of chickenpox in pregnancy includes:
    • Oral Acyclovir if within 24 hours of the onset of the rash and if the gestational age is greater than 20 weeks.
    • Intravenous Acyclovir should be given to all pregnant women with severe chickenpox.
  • VZIG has no therapeutic benefit once chickenpox has started.
  • Women who develop chickenpox in pregnancy should be referred to a fetal medicine specialist at 16–20 weeks or 5 weeks after infection to look for congenital varicella syndrome.
  • If the infection occurs in the last 4 weeks of pregnancy, there is a risk of varicella infection in the newborn. Planned delivery should normally be avoided for at least 7 days after the onset of the maternal rash to allow for the passive transfer of antibodies from mother to child.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Immune to chickenpox: A negative antibody test does not signify immunity; it signifies susceptibility.

 

Option C. Susceptible to zoster: Varicella-zoster virus causes both chickenpox (primary infection) and shingles (reactivation). A negative test for varicella antibodies indicates susceptibility to the primary infection (chickenpox), not to shingles.

 

Option D. Immune to zoster: Immunity to zoster would imply prior exposure to the varicella-zoster virus, which is not indicated by a negative varicella antibody test.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A negative varicella antibody test in a pregnant woman indicates that she is susceptible to chickenpox and should receive VZIG if exposed.

 

Ref: Page no 3085, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: Implantation of the embryo takes place how many days after fertilization? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 8


Implantation of the embryo typically starts around 5 to 6 days after fertilization and is usually completed by 8 to 9 days. After fertilization, the embryo undergoes several stages of development, including cleavage and blastocyst formation. The blastocyst travels down the fallopian tube and reaches the uterus by around day 5. It then begins to attach to and invade the uterine lining, completing the implantation process by around day 8. Therefore, 8 days is the most accurate answer representing the completion of the implantation process.

 

 

Educational Objective:


Implantation of the embryo begins around day 5 to 6 and is completed by day 8 to 9 after fertilization.

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman presented at 7 weeks of gestation, unwilling to continue the pregnancy. What are the drugs used for medical termination of pregnancy in this patient? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Misoprostol and Mifepristone

 

Explanation:

 

  • Misoprostol and Mifepristone:
    • The drugs used for medical termination of pregnancy (MTP) in this patient presenting at 7 weeks of gestation are misoprostol and mifepristone.
    • Mifepristone 200 mg is administered orally on day 1. It acts as an antiprogestogen, blocking the effects of progesterone, which is essential to maintain pregnancy.
    • Misoprostol is given 24-48 hours after mifepristone. Misoprostol, a prostaglandin E1 analog, induces uterine contractions to expel the pregnancy tissue.
    • Clinical confirmation of MTP is done on day 14 through clinical examination and/or ultrasonography to ensure the complete expulsion of the products of conception.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Misoprostol and Medroxyprogesterone: Medroxyprogesterone is a synthetic progestin used in contraception and hormone replacement therapy but is not used in medical termination of pregnancy.

 

Option C. Mifepristone and Methotrexate: Methotrexate is a folate antagonist that can be used in combination with misoprostol for medical termination of pregnancy, especially in early gestations, but it is not the standard regimen compared to mifepristone and misoprostol.

 

Option D. Mifepristone and Medroxyprogesterone: Medroxyprogesterone is not used in medical termination of pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For medical termination of pregnancy at 7 weeks of gestation, the recommended drugs are mifepristone followed by misoprostol.

 

 

Ref: https://main.mohfw.gov.in/acts-rules-and-standards-health-sector/acts/mtp-rules

questions.text: Patient experiences softening of the cervix in early pregnancy. This sign is called as? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Goodell

 

Goodell's sign refers to the softening of the cervix, which is observed during early pregnancy. This sign occurs due to increased vascularization and changes in the connective tissue of the cervix, making it feel softer compared to the non-pregnant state, where the cervix feels firm like the tip of the nose.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Osiander: This is incorrect. Osiander’s sign refers to the palpable pulsation of the uterine arteries felt through the lateral fornices during a vaginal examination in early pregnancy.

 

Option B. Chadwick: This is incorrect. Chadwick's sign, also known as Jacquemier’s sign, is the bluish discoloration of the vaginal mucosa and cervix due to increased blood flow during early pregnancy.

 

Option D. Hegar: This is incorrect. Hegar's sign involves the softening of the lower uterine segment, which is palpable during a bimanual examination, allowing the examiner's fingers to approximate between the uterus and the cervix.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Goodell's sign is the softening of the cervix, observed in early pregnancy due to increased vascularity, which makes the cervix feel soft, like the lips, compared to its usual firm texture

questions.text: All of the following are risk factors of vulval cancer except? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vulval hamartoma

 

Vulval cancer has several known risk factors, which include:

 

  • Chronic vulval irritation: Persistent irritation and inflammation can contribute to the development of vulval cancer.
  • Immunosuppressive conditions: Conditions such as pregnancy and HIV infection can compromise the immune system, increasing the risk of vulval cancer.
  • HPV (Human Papillomavirus): Infection with HPV, particularly strains 16 and 18, is a significant risk factor.
  • Smoking: Smoking is a known risk factor for various cancers, including vulval cancer.
  • Condyloma (anogenital warts): Caused by HPV, these warts can lead to changes in vulval cells that may progress to cancer.
  • Sexually transmitted diseases (STDs): History of STDs can increase the risk due to the association with HPV and chronic inflammation.
  • Vulvar dystrophies: Conditions like lichen sclerosus can predispose individuals to vulval cancer.

 

Vulval hamartoma is not a risk factor for vulval cancer. Hamartomas are benign, disorganized clusters of tissue that do not typically transform into malignant tumors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vulval dystrophy: Vulval dystrophies, such as lichen sclerosus, are risk factors for vulval cancer due to chronic irritation and inflammation.

 

Option C. Smoking: Smoking is a well-documented risk factor for many cancers, including vulval cancer.

 

Option D. Vulval warts: Vulval warts, often caused by HPV, can lead to cellular changes that increase the risk of vulval cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vulval hamartomas are not a risk factor for vulval cancer, while chronic irritation, immunosuppressive conditions, HPV infection, smoking, anogenital warts, STDs, and vulvar dystrophies are known risk factors.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of gynecology 3rd edition pg 680, Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6th edition pg 334

questions.text: A 5-year-old came with complaints of swollen and bleeding gums, fatigue, bone pains. On further examination, petechie are seen. What is the best possible diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Vitamin C

 

The symptoms described, including swollen and bleeding gums, fatigue, bone pains, and petechiae, are consistent with scurvy, which is caused by Vitamin C deficiency. Vitamin C is essential for collagen synthesis, and its deficiency leads to impaired wound healing, weakened blood vessels, and bleeding gums.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin A: Vitamin A deficiency can lead to night blindness and xerophthalmia but is not typically associated with swollen and bleeding gums, bone pains, or petechiae. Vitamin A deficiency is more commonly linked with ocular manifestations and immune system impairment.

 

Option B. Vitamin D: Vitamin D deficiency can cause rickets in children, characterized by bone pain and deformities. However, swollen and bleeding gums, fatigue, and petechiae are not typical symptoms of Vitamin D deficiency. Furthermore, bone pains in rickets are usually associated with skeletal deformities rather than generalized bone pain.

 

Option D. Vitamin K: Vitamin K deficiency can lead to impaired blood clotting, resulting in excessive bleeding. While Vitamin K deficiency can cause petechiae due to bleeding disorders, it is not typically associated with swollen and bleeding gums, fatigue, or bone pains.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The symptoms of swollen and bleeding gums, fatigue, bone pains, and petechiae in a child are characteristic of scurvy, which is caused by Vitamin C deficiency.

questions.text: A 30-year-old P2L2 woman presents with cervical elongation. Her family is complete. What is the preferred surgery advised? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fothergill


The Fothergill procedure, also known as the Manchester repair, is the preferred surgical treatment for women with cervical elongation who have completed their families and do not wish to have more children. This procedure involves cervical amputation and reinforcement of the pelvic ligaments, providing adequate support without removing the uterus. It is suitable for younger women who are not candidates for a hysterectomy but have significant cervical elongation contributing to prolapse symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. McCall Culdoplasty: This procedure is typically performed to correct vaginal vault prolapse during or after hysterectomy and is not specifically indicated for cervical elongation.

 

Option C. Le fort: This procedure involves partial closure of the vagina and is generally recommended for elderly, non-sexually active women who are not candidates for more invasive surgeries.

 

Option D. Shirodkar sling: This procedure is used for pelvic organ prolapse in young, nulliparous women or women who wish to preserve fertility by anchoring the uterus, usually to the sacral promontory. It is not indicated for women with completed families and cervical elongation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Prolapse management by age group:

questions.text: Following delivery at a PHC, a patient was referred with the following image. On examination, there is a tear extending to the rectum. Identify the type of tear. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 4th degree


Perineal tears are classified based on the extent of tissue damage during childbirth:

 

  1. 1st degree: Involves only the vaginal mucosa or skin of the perineum without involving deeper tissues.
  2. 2nd degree: Extends deeper, involving the perineal muscles but does not reach the anal sphincters; similar to an episiotomy.
  3. 3rd degree: Involves the anal sphincter complex with further sub-classifications:
    • 3a: Less than 50% of the external anal sphincter is torn.
    • 3b: More than 50% of the external anal sphincter is torn.
    • 3c: Both the external and internal anal sphincters are involved.
  4. 4th degree: Extends through the rectal mucosa, completely disrupting the sphincters and the rectal lining.

 

Since the tear extends to the rectum, this is classified as a 4th degree tear, the most severe type, involving the entire perineum, anal sphincters, and rectal mucosa.

 

Educational Objective:


A 4th degree tear involves disruption of the anal sphincters and rectal mucosa, making it the most severe form of perineal tear during childbirth.

choices.text: LH from maternal pituitary
HCG from placenta
Inhibin from corpus luteum
GnRH from fetal hypothalamus

questions.text: Testosterone helps in the development of various organs in the fetus. Which of the following stimulates its production? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) HCG from placenta

 

Explanation:

 

  • HCG from placenta:
    • HCG (human chorionic gonadotropin) from the placenta stimulates the production of testosterone in the male fetus.
    • HCG released from the placenta is the initial stimulus for testosterone production in the male fetus.
    • Later by the eighth week of gestation, fetal pituitary LH (luteinizing hormone) stimulates the Leydig cells of the testes to produce testosterone.
    • Sex differentiation of the embryo depends on the Y chromosome, which contains the testis-determining gene called the SRY (sex-determining region on Y) gene.
    • In a genetically male embryo (46, XY), the gonad is converted into testis under the influence of this gene.
    • Female development (Mullerian ducts) occurs in the absence of this gene.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. LH from maternal pituitary: Maternal LH does not play a role in fetal testosterone production. The fetal pituitary gland, not the maternal pituitary, influences testosterone production later in gestation.

 

Option C. Inhibin from corpus luteum: Inhibin is involved in the regulation of FSH and does not stimulate testosterone production. It primarily acts to provide feedback inhibition to the anterior pituitary gland to control FSH levels.

 

Option D. GnRH from fetal hypothalamus: GnRH (gonadotropin-releasing hormone) from the fetal hypothalamus plays a role in stimulating the fetal pituitary to release LH and FSH, but it is not the initial trigger for testosterone production in the fetus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

HCG from the placenta is the initial stimulus for testosterone production in the male fetus.

 

Ref: Page 103, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: Karyotype is 46 XY
Ovotestis is seen in the gonadal biopsy
The response of testosterone to hCG is increased
Uterus is usually absent

questions.text: What is true about ovotesticular disorders of sex development? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ovotestis is seen in the gonadal biopsy

 

  • Ovotesticular disorder of sex development (DSD) is characterized by the presence of both ovarian and testicular tissue in the same individual.
  • Most affected individuals have a 46, XX chromosomal karyotype, which normally results in female sexual development.
  • In about 10% of patients, testicular tissue in an individual with a 46, XX karyotype is present as a result of a translocation of the SRY gene on the Y chromosome to the X chromosome or another chromosome.
  • An abnormal vagina and underdeveloped uterus are usually present.
  • The testes are usually undescended, and the penis may present with hypospadias.
  • Upon reaching puberty, breast development, feminization, and menstruation may occur.
  • Most affected individuals are infertile, but ovulation or spermatogenesis is possible.
  • The response of testosterone to hCG is normal or reduced.
  • A defect in R-spondin1 protein encoded by the RSPO1 gene is described in 46, XX ovotesticular DSD.
  • An ovotestis is present in approximately 2/3 of affected individuals.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ovotesticular disorder of sex development is characterized by the presence of both ovarian and testicular tissues, typically with a 46, XX karyotype and possible SRY gene translocation, and can present with ovotestis seen on gonadal biopsy.

choices.text: Ultrasound showing streak ovaries and a small uterus
Ultrasound showing hepatomegaly with altered echotexture

questions.text: A 12-year girl is brought to the OPD by her mother. She is concerned that she is shorter than her peers. On examination there is ptosis on the right side, shield like chest and a webbed neck. On evaluation, which of the following is the most definitive finding? (NEET PG 2021 )
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ultrasound showing streak ovaries and a small uterus

 

Explanation:

 

Turner Syndrome:

 

  • Turner syndrome is a chromosomal disorder affecting females, characterized by the absence of all or part of one X chromosome (45,XO).
  • It presents with several distinct clinical features.

 

Clinical Features of Turner Syndrome:

 

  • Short stature: Typically shorter than peers, often the first noticeable symptom.
  • Primary amenorrhea: Due to streak gonads (non-functioning ovaries).
  • Shield-like chest: Broad chest with widely spaced nipples.
  • Webbed neck: Excess skin folds running from the tops of the shoulders to the sides of the neck.
  • Ptosis: Drooping of the upper eyelid, can be unilateral or bilateral.
  • Cardiac defects: Commonly coarctation of the aorta, though ventricular septal defects (VSD) can also occur but are less common.
  • Renal anomalies: Such as horseshoe kidney or a single kidney.
  • Other features: Low-set ears, high-arched palate, arms that turn outward at the elbows, narrow and turned-up fingernails and toenails, low hairline at the back of the head, receding or small lower jaw.

 

Ultrasound Findings:

 

  • The presence of streak ovaries (underdeveloped ovaries) and a small uterus are typical findings in Turner syndrome, leading to primary amenorrhea and infertility.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. ECHO shows VSD: While Turner syndrome can involve congenital heart defects, the most common cardiac anomalies are coarctation of the aorta and bicuspid aortic valve, not ventricular septal defect (VSD).

 

Option C. Ultrasound showing hepatomegaly with altered echotexture: This is not typically associated with Turner syndrome. Hepatomegaly might suggest liver disease or metabolic disorders, which are not characteristic of Turner syndrome.

 

Option D. Ultrasound showing single kidney: Renal anomalies can occur in Turner syndrome, such as a horseshoe kidney or a single kidney, but the primary findings expected include streak ovaries and a small uterus which are more specific for Turner syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Turner syndrome is characterized by a 45,XO genotype, primary amenorrhea, short stature, and distinctive physical features such as a webbed neck and shield-like chest. Ultrasound typically shows streak ovaries and a small uterus.

 

Ref: Page no 411, Williams Gynecology 3rd edition

choices.text: Leave the IUCD in situ

questions.text: A 26-year-old conceives on the IUCD. Wants to continue pregnancy. Next best step? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Remove the IUCD gently

 

The Ans. is Remove the IUCD gently. When a woman becomes pregnant with an intrauterine contraceptive device (IUCD) in place and wishes to continue the pregnancy, the IUCD should be removed if possible. Leaving the IUCD in situ is associated with risks such as preterm labor, fetal growth restriction, and potential fetal anomalies. While removing the IUCD does carry a slightly increased risk of miscarriage, the overall benefits of removal outweigh the risks of leaving it in place. Removal should be done carefully, with appropriate counseling provided to the patient about the potential risks involved.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Leave the IUCD in situ: Leaving the IUCD in place is not recommended as it can lead to complications like preterm labor, fetal growth restriction, and other pregnancy complications. Therefore, it should be removed if the patient wishes to continue the pregnancy.

 

Option C. MTP (Medical Termination of Pregnancy): MTP is not appropriate in this scenario because the patient wishes to continue with the pregnancy. The focus should be on managing the pregnancy safely with the IUCD removed.

 

Option D. Progesterone support: Progesterone support is not indicated in this case as it does not address the main issue, which is the presence of the IUCD and its associated risks if left in place during pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When a pregnancy occurs with an IUCD in place and the patient wishes to continue, the IUCD should be removed gently to minimize risks associated with leaving it in situ.

questions.text: The commonest indication for liver transplantation in children is: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Biliary atresia

 

Liver transplantation is a crucial life-saving procedure for children with liver failure. The most common indication for liver transplantation in children is biliary atresia. Biliary atresia is a condition characterized by a blockage in the bile ducts outside the liver, leading to progressive liver damage and cirrhosis.

 

For infants diagnosed with biliary atresia, a surgical procedure known as hepatoportoenterostomy (Kasai procedure) is performed to establish bile drainage. However, if the Kasai procedure is not successful in restoring bile flow, liver transplantation becomes necessary, often within the first year of life.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alagille syndrome: This syndrome, characterized by butterfly-shaped vertebrae and congenital heart disease (often pulmonary stenosis), results in infantile cholestasis due to a syndromic paucity of intralobular bile ducts. It is a less common indication for liver transplantation compared to biliary atresia.

 

Option C. Caroli disease: This is a rare congenital disorder characterized by dilation of the intrahepatic bile ducts. While it can lead to liver failure, it is not the most common indication for liver transplantation in children.

 

Option D. Hepatocellular carcinoma: This is a rare cause of liver transplantation in children. While liver tumors can necessitate transplantation, they are less common compared to biliary atresia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Biliary atresia is the most common indication for liver transplantation in children due to the progressive liver damage and cirrhosis caused by bile duct obstruction.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child with stable vitals and ECG showing PSVT. What is the appropriate management? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Adenosine 0.1 mg/kg

     

The management of paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT) in a stable child begins with pharmacological intervention rather than immediate cardioversion. Adenosine is the drug of choice for PSVT due to its ability to temporarily block the atrioventricular node, effectively terminating the arrhythmia.

 

The initial dose of adenosine recommended is 0.1 mg/kg given as a rapid IV bolus over 1-3 seconds. If there is no response, subsequent doses can be increased to 0.2 mg/kg, and if necessary, 0.3 mg/kg can be administered under monitored conditions. Rapid bolus administration is essential, followed by a 5-10 ml of saline flush to ensure the drug reaches systemic circulation quickly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cardioversion: Cardioversion is typically reserved for cases where the patient is unstable or when pharmacological management fails. In a stable patient, the initial approach is to use adenosine to terminate the PSVT without the need for electrical intervention.

 

Option B. Adenosine 0.3 mg per kg: While this dosage of adenosine can be used if initial doses do not work, it is not the starting dose. The initial dose should be lower, at 0.1 mg/kg, to minimize potential adverse effects.

 

Option C. Adenosine 0.2 mg/kg: This dose of adenosine is appropriate for a second attempt if the initial dose (0.1 mg/kg) does not resolve the PSVT. It is not the first-line dose but can be escalated to after the initial dose fails.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For stable PSVT in children, adenosine is the first-line treatment, starting at a dose of 0.1 mg/kg. If this dose is ineffective, the dose may be escalated in subsequent attempts.

questions.text: A young woman presents with prolapse. A sacrohysteropexy is being done. A mesh is being placed. Where is this mesh fixed to? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Sacral promontory

 

In cases of pelvic organ prolapse, surgical procedures like sacrocolpopexy or sacrohysteropexy are performed to provide support to the prolapsed organs using a mesh.

 

  • In sacrocolpopexy, the mesh is typically fixed from the vaginal vault (in patients who have undergone a hysterectomy) to the sacral promontory.
  • In sacrohysteropexy, the mesh is fixed from the cervix to the sacral promontory, providing support to the uterus in younger patients who still have their uterus intact.

 

The sacral promontory, which is the uppermost part of the sacrum, serves as a strong and reliable point for attachment, providing the necessary support to the pelvic structures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ischial spine: The ischial spine is a point of attachment for pelvic muscles and ligaments, but it is not used for mesh fixation in sacrocolpopexy or sacrohysteropexy.

 

Option B. Ischial tuberosity: This structure serves as an attachment site for muscles and ligaments of the pelvis, but it is not involved in sacrocolpopexy procedures.

 

Option D. Pubic symphysis: This is a cartilaginous joint connecting the left and right pubic bones. It is not utilized as a fixation point in sacrocolpopexy or sacrohysteropexy surgeries.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In sacrocolpopexy and sacrohysteropexy procedures for pelvic organ prolapse, the mesh is fixed to the sacral promontory, providing strong support to the prolapsed organs.

choices.text: Age 6 months – 5 years
Simple febrile seizure lasts for <15 minutes
No need for long term antiepileptics

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true about febrile seizure?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 54% recurrence

 

Febrile seizures are convulsions brought on by a fever in infants or small children. They are relatively common and typically occur between the ages of 6 months and 5 years. The main features of febrile seizures include:

 

  • Age 6 months – 5 years: This is the typical age range for febrile seizures, making this statement true.
  • Simple febrile seizure lasts for <15 minutes: Simple febrile seizures are brief, usually lasting less than 15 minutes. This statement is also true.
  • No need for long term antiepileptic: In the case of simple febrile seizures, long-term antiepileptic treatment is generally not necessary. This statement is true as well.

 

The statement "54% recurrence" is not true. The recurrence rate for febrile seizures is significantly lower. While there is a risk of recurrence, it is not as high as 54%.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Febrile seizures typically occur between the ages of 6 months and 5 years, last less than 15 minutes, and do not require long-term antiepileptic treatment. The recurrence rate is much lower than 54%.

choices.text: Sertoli cell only syndrome
﻿﻿﻿Benign testicular neoplasm

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient is evaluated for primary infertility. Semen analysis shows azoospermia. A testicular biopsy is done and the image is shown below. The shown finding is consistent with? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sertoli cell only syndrome

 

Explanation:

 

  • Sertoli cell only syndrome:
    • The given clinical scenario and the biopsy findings are consistent with the diagnosis of Sertoli cell-only syndrome.
    • Patients with Sertoli cell-only syndrome typically present between the ages of 20 and 40 years with primary infertility.
    • Diagnosis is confirmed through testicular biopsy.
    • The histopathology of the biopsy specimen typically shows seminiferous tubules populated by only Sertoli cells, with thickening of the tubular basement membrane and absence of germ cells, which is characteristic of Sertoli cell-only syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Testicular atrophy: Testicular atrophy may present with decreased testicular volume and could be due to various causes like mumps orchitis, trauma, or varicocele. The histopathological findings would not specifically show the absence of germ cells with the presence of only Sertoli cells.

 

Option C. Benign testicular neoplasm: Benign testicular neoplasms would present with a mass in the testis and would show specific neoplastic cells on histopathology rather than the absence of germ cells.

 

Option D. Orchitis: Orchitis typically presents with inflammation, pain, and swelling of the testes, and the biopsy would show inflammatory infiltrates rather than the absence of germ cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sertoli cell-only syndrome is characterized by primary infertility and azoospermia, with testicular biopsy showing seminiferous tubules populated only by Sertoli cells and absence of germ cells.

 

Ref: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC7910341/

choices.text: Emergency cesarean facility should be there

questions.text: Correct about trial of labor in a previous LSCS (Lower Segment Cesarean Section) is? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Emergency cesarean facility should be there

 

Explanation:

 

The correct answer is emergency cesarean facility should be there. When considering a trial of labor after cesarean (TOLAC), it is crucial to ensure that the facility is equipped to handle an emergency cesarean section. This is because the risk of complications, including uterine rupture, can pose significant risks to both the mother and the fetus.

 

Emergency cesarean facility: The availability of an emergency cesarean section facility is essential for any patient undergoing TOLAC. This ensures that if complications arise, such as uterine rupture, immediate surgical intervention can be provided to minimize risks.

 

Other Option:

 

Option A. Risk of uterine rupture is 4-9%: This statement is incorrect for a lower segment cesarean section. The risk of uterine rupture in a TOLAC for a lower segment cesarean section is much lower, around 0.2%. The 4-9% risk applies to upper segment or classical cesarean sections.

 

Additional Considerations for TOLAC:

 

  1. Interval between pregnancies: The inter-delivery interval should be more than 18 months to allow adequate healing of the uterine scar.
  2. Reason for previous cesarean: Conditions like cephalopelvic disproportion (CPD) or other recurrent indications may reduce the likelihood of a successful TOLAC and increase the risk of complications.
  3. Monitoring: Continuous fetal monitoring during labor is recommended to detect any signs of fetal distress early.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When attempting a trial of labor after cesarean (TOLAC), ensure that an emergency cesarean facility is available to handle any complications, particularly the risk of uterine rupture.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with heavy menstrual bleeding and something coming out of the vagina. Her last childbirth was 10 years back. On bimanual palpation, the uterus is palpable. On examination, the cervix admits 1 finger, and the following is seen. What is the probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Fibroid polyp

 

The clinical presentation, including heavy menstrual bleeding, the presence of a vaginal mass, and the fact that the uterus is palpable on bimanual examination, strongly suggests a fibroid polyp. A fibroid polyp is a type of submucosal fibroid that protrudes into the uterine cavity and may extend through the cervix into the vagina. It can cause abnormal uterine bleeding, including intermenstrual bleeding, due to the exposed surface of the polyp that can easily get eroded.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Adenomyoma: This is incorrect. Adenomyoma, a localized form of adenomyosis, typically presents similarly to fibroids but does not cause a vaginal mass. The uterus would also be enlarged, and the cervix would not be open to admit a finger.

 

Option C. Intramural fibroid: This is incorrect. Intramural fibroids grow within the muscular wall of the uterus and do not typically protrude through the cervix to present as a vaginal mass. The uterus would be enlarged, and the cervix would not be open.

 

Option D. Inversion: This is incorrect. Uterine inversion usually occurs postpartum, often immediately after childbirth, or it can present as a chronic condition that began after a previous childbirth. In inversion, the uterus is typically not palpable on bimanual examination because it has turned inside out. The cervix would not admit a finger as the entire uterus is inside out, blocking access.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A fibroid polyp presents with heavy menstrual bleeding, a palpable uterus on bimanual examination, and a protruding mass in the vagina due to the fibroid extending through the cervix

questions.text: Identify the maneuver? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Burn Marshall

 

The Burns Marshall maneuver is a technique used during breech deliveries. This maneuver involves gently swinging the baby over the maternal abdomen by holding the baby's ankles. The purpose is to facilitate the delivery of the after-coming head in breech presentation. It requires careful handling to avoid neck injury and to maintain control during delivery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Wigand: The Wigand maneuver is another technique used in obstetrics, but it is not related to breech delivery or involves swinging the baby over the maternal abdomen.

 

Option C. Mauriceau Smellie Viet: This maneuver is used during breech delivery but involves supporting the baby's body on the obstetrician's forearm with the index and middle fingers placed on the maxilla to flex the head. It does not involve swinging the baby and is distinct from the Burns Marshall maneuver.

 

 

Option D. Prague: The Prague maneuver is used in breech delivery, specifically when the baby's arms are extended above the head. The obstetrician rotates the baby to facilitate arm delivery before the head, differing from the Burns Marshall maneuver.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Burns Marshall maneuver is characterized by gently swinging the baby over the maternal abdomen to assist in the delivery of the after-coming head in breech presentation.

questions.text: A G3P2L1NND1 presents at 37 weeks with previous 2 LSCS with primary active HSV. What is the next best step? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) LSCS (Lower Segment Cesarean Section)


In a patient with a history of two previous lower segment cesarean sections (LSCS) and active primary herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection at 37 weeks of gestation, an elective LSCS is the safest approach. Active HSV infection is a contraindication to vaginal delivery due to the high risk of neonatal herpes transmission, which can lead to severe complications in the newborn. A classical cesarean (vertical incision on the upper uterus) is not indicated here because the LSCS provides a safer and more appropriate route without the additional risks associated with classical cesareans, such as increased bleeding and uterine rupture in future pregnancies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Classical cesarean: A classical cesarean involves a vertical incision on the upper uterine segment and is generally reserved for cases where lower segment access is challenging, such as in preterm deliveries or certain uterine anomalies. It is not warranted here and would increase future obstetric risks.

 

Option C.  VBAC (Vaginal Birth After Cesarean): VBAC is contraindicated in this case due to active HSV infection and the risk of neonatal transmission. Additionally, VBAC is not recommended after two previous cesareans, especially when other complications like active infection are present.

 

Option D. IOL (Induction of Labor): Inducing labor is contraindicated in patients with active HSV due to the risk of viral transmission to the baby during delivery. This approach would pose significant risks without any benefit in this clinical scenario.

 

Educational Objective:


Active herpes simplex virus infection during labor is an indication for a cesarean section to prevent neonatal transmission.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child presents with diarrhea and weight loss. On examination, the height and weight are lesser than expected. Laboratory investigations were positive for class II HLA-DQ2. Which of the following will you advise the child? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Gluten-free diet

 

The positive HLA-DQ2 and the presentation of diarrhea and weight loss in a child suggest the possibility of celiac disease. Therefore, the child should be advised to follow a gluten-free diet.

 

Celiac disease is a condition characterized by an abnormal immune response to gluten, a protein found in wheat, barley, and rye. This immune response leads to damage to the small intestine and malabsorption of nutrients, which can result in diarrhea, weight loss, and other symptoms.

 

HLA-DQ2 is a genetic marker that is present in over 90% of individuals with celiac disease. Therefore, a positive test for HLA-DQ2 can suggest the possibility of celiac disease, although a definitive diagnosis requires further testing, such as serologic testing and intestinal biopsy.

 

The pathogenesis of celiac disease involves an inflammatory response to gluten and gliadin, a gluten-derived peptide. In the small intestine, gliadin is deamidated by an intestinal enzyme called tissue transglutaminase (tTG), resulting in a more immunogenic form of the protein that is presented to helper T cells. This leads to mucosal inflammation, tissue damage, and other symptoms.

 

Children with celiac disease typically present with diarrhea, weight loss, and growth failure. Other symptoms may include malabsorption, bloating, irregular bowel habits, iron deficiency anemia, osteoporosis, ataxia, and abnormal liver enzymes. Screening for celiac disease is performed by testing for serum antibodies, including tissue transglutaminase IgA, anti-endomysial, and deaminated anti-gliadin antibodies. The diagnosis is confirmed in patients with positive antibodies by biopsy of the second part of the duodenum or proximal jejunum. Microscopic examination of the biopsy sample reveals intraepithelial CD8+ lymphocytes, villous atrophy, and crypt hyperplasia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fat-free diet: This is not relevant to the management of celiac disease. Fat intake is not directly related to the immune response triggered by gluten.

 

Option B. Lactose-free diet: While some individuals with celiac disease may temporarily develop lactose intolerance due to mucosal damage, a lactose-free diet is not the primary treatment.

 

Option C. Low carbohydrate diet: This diet is not related to the management of celiac disease. The primary issue is the immune response to gluten, not carbohydrate intake.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Children with celiac disease should follow a gluten-free diet to manage symptoms and prevent further intestinal damage.

questions.text: Most common site of genital TB is? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Fallopian tube

 

Explanation:

 

Genital tuberculosis (TB) primarily affects the female reproductive system, with the fallopian tubes being the most common site of infection. Tuberculous salpingitis can lead to various complications, including:

 

  • Endosalpingitis or Exosalpingitis: Inflammation inside or around the fallopian tubes.
  • Beading of the tube: Formation of small nodular masses or swellings along the tube.
  • Constriction of the tube: Narrowing of the tube, which can obstruct the passage of the ovum.
  • Hydrosalpinx: Accumulation of fluid in the fallopian tube, often due to obstruction caused by TB.

 

These complications can significantly impact fertility, making infertility a common issue in women with genital TB.

 

Other Options:

 

Other Sites of Genital TB:

 

Option A. Cervix: Less commonly affected.

 

Option B. Endometrium: Can be involved, but not as frequently as the fallopian tubes.
 

Option D. Ovary: Also less commonly affected compared to the fallopian tubes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The fallopian tube is the most common site of genital tuberculosis, leading to significant complications such as salpingitis, hydrosalpinx, and infertility.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding perimortem cesarean section? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Upper segment cesarean section

 

Explanation:

 

An upper segment cesarean section is performed during a perimortem cesarean section (PMCS). PMCS is an emergency cesarean delivery of a woman who is expected to die within the next few moments or has just died.

 

Key points about PMCS:

 

  • Timing: According to the AHA 2020 Guidelines for CPR, perimortem cesarean should be considered if there is no return of spontaneous circulation within 5 minutes in a pregnant woman who has experienced total cardiopulmonary arrest.
  • Purpose: The goal of PMCS is to improve maternal and fetal outcomes by relieving the compression of the inferior vena cava (IVC) by the gravid uterus, which enhances venous return and diaphragmatic displacement. This, in turn, improves respiratory dynamics and resuscitative efforts.
  • Fetal Outcome: The infant has a higher chance of survival if PMCS is performed within 10 minutes of maternal death.
  • Surgical Technique: A classical upper-segment cesarean section with a vertical uterine incision is performed.
  • Location: PMCS does not need to be done in the operating theatre (OT); it can be done wherever the patient is located to expedite the process.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. LSCS: Lower segment cesarean section (LSCS) is not typically used in PMCS.

 

Option B. Pfannenstiel incision: This is a horizontal incision typically used in elective cesarean sections, not in emergency PMCS.
