Option D. Done in OT: PMCS does not need to be performed in the operating theatre; it can be done immediately at the site of the patient to save time.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Perimortem cesarean section (PMCS) involves performing a classical upper-segment cesarean section with a vertical uterine incision in an emergency situation to improve maternal and fetal outcomes.

 

Ref: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK459265/

questions.text: Identify this instrument used in the delivery of the aftercoming head in breech. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Piper forceps

 

Piper forceps are specifically designed for the delivery of the aftercoming head in breech presentations. Their unique shape allows them to grasp the head of the baby gently and guide it through the birth canal without applying excessive pressure. The long, curved shanks of Piper forceps are particularly adapted for use when the baby is in breech position, making them the most appropriate tool for this scenario.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Wrigley forceps: These are outlet forceps used when the fetal head is at +3 station, fully or nearly fully rotated. They are not designed for use in breech presentations.

 

 

Option C. Kielland forceps: These are rotational forceps used when the fetal head is high and unrotated. They are meant for complex cases where rotation of the head is necessary, not for the aftercoming head in breech.

 

 

Option D. Dass forceps: These are low forceps used when the fetal head is at +2 station. They are not suitable for the delivery of the aftercoming head in breech as they are not designed for such specific maneuvering.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Piper forceps are the instrument of choice for the delivery of the aftercoming head in breech presentations due to their specialized design that facilitates safe extraction.

questions.text: A pregnant lady with a history of recurrent abortions is now diagnosed to have antiphospholipid syndrome. What would be the best mode of treatment for her? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Aspirin + heparin

 

Explanation

 

Aspirin + heparin:

 

  • Antiphospholipid syndrome (APS) is an autoimmune disorder characterized by recurrent pregnancy loss, thrombosis, and the presence of antiphospholipid antibodies.
  • The primary cause of pregnancy loss in APS is believed to be due to inhibition of trophoblast function and differentiation, which leads to placental dysfunction.
  • The best management approach for pregnant women with APS includes:
    • Low dose aspirin: Initiated as soon as pregnancy is confirmed. Aspirin helps by preventing platelet aggregation and improving blood flow to the placenta.
    • Low Molecular Weight Heparin (LMWH): Started once fetal cardiac activity is detected. LMWH helps prevent blood clot formation, thus reducing the risk of thrombosis and improving pregnancy outcomes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aspirin only: While low-dose aspirin is beneficial, it is not sufficient alone for the prevention of complications in APS. The addition of heparin provides better protection against thrombosis and pregnancy loss.

 

Option C. Aspirin + heparin + steroids: Steroids are not routinely used in the management of APS during pregnancy due to their potential side effects and lack of evidence showing added benefit in preventing pregnancy loss when combined with aspirin and heparin.

 

Option D. Aspirin + steroids: Similar to the previous option, steroids are not recommended as part of the standard management for APS in pregnancy. The combination of aspirin and heparin is the preferred treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The best management for pregnant women with antiphospholipid syndrome (APS) to prevent recurrent pregnancy loss includes low-dose aspirin and low molecular weight heparin (LMWH).

 

Ref: Page no 2907, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: LSCS (Lower Segment Cesarean Section) for breech was done. Intraoperatively, this was seen. Two cervixes were also identified. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Uterine didelphys

 

Uterine didelphys is a congenital uterine anomaly characterized by the presence of two separate uterine cavities, each with its own cervix, due to the failure of the Müllerian ducts to fuse during fetal development. The presence of two cervices identified intraoperatively strongly indicates uterine didelphys, where each cervix is associated with its own uterine body.

 

In the image, the appearance of two distinctly separate uterine bodies confirms the diagnosis. One uterus appears larger because it likely accommodated the pregnancy, while the other uterus remains smaller. This anomaly often presents during procedures like cesarean sections, where the characteristic appearance of two separate uterine structures is noted.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Arcuate uterus: This is a mild form of uterine anomaly characterized by a slight indentation at the top of the uterine cavity. It does not present with two separate uterine bodies or two cervices.

 

Option B. Bicornuate uterus: This condition features a single cervix with a heart-shaped uterine cavity, partially divided into two horns. It does not have two completely separate uterine bodies or cervices.

 

Option C. Unicornuate uterus: This anomaly is characterized by a single uterine horn with only one cervix, often associated with a rudimentary horn. It does not present as two separate uterine structures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Uterine didelphys is characterized by two separate uterine cavities, each with its own cervix, due to a failure of Müllerian duct fusion during fetal development.

questions.text: One mother had brought her child for evaluation of diphtheria in which the child had low-grade fever, pseudomembranes over the tonsils, and one sibling is fully immunized. What will be the prophylaxis given to her sibling? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Erythromycin

 

The Ans. is Erythromycin. In cases where a household member is diagnosed with diphtheria, all close contacts, including fully immunized siblings, should be given prophylactic treatment regardless of their immunization status.

 

The recommended prophylaxis for contacts is oral Erythromycin for seven days or a single dose of benzathine penicillin. This approach aims to prevent the spread of Corynebacterium diphtheriae and the development of active diphtheria lesions in contacts, even if they are asymptomatic and immunized.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Diphtheria booster single dose: A booster dose of the diphtheria toxoid is recommended for previously immunized individuals who are diagnosed with diphtheria but are asymptomatic. This does not apply to the contact sibling who is already fully immunized and not infected.

 

Option C. Diphtheria toxoid full course: A full course of the diphtheria toxoid is not necessary for a fully immunized sibling who is a contact. This option would be considered for individuals who are not up-to-date with their diphtheria vaccinations.

 

Option D. Nothing is required: This option is incorrect because all household contacts of a diphtheria case should receive prophylactic treatment to prevent possible infection and transmission, even if they are asymptomatic and fully immunized.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For fully immunized close contacts of a diphtheria case, the recommended prophylaxis is a seven-day course of oral Erythromycin or a single dose of benzathine penicillin.

questions.text: Which is the most common electrolyte imbalance seen in pyloric stenosis? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hypokalemia

 

Pyloric stenosis is a condition where the opening from the stomach to the small intestine (the pylorus) becomes narrowed. This causes severe vomiting, which leads to the loss of stomach acid (hydrochloric acid). The loss of hydrochloric acid results in a metabolic alkalosis state.

 

In addition to the loss of stomach acid, vomiting leads to the depletion of various electrolytes, including sodium, potassium, and chloride. Among these, hypokalemia (low potassium levels) is the most common and significant electrolyte imbalance seen in pyloric stenosis. The continuous vomiting depletes potassium levels more profoundly than other electrolytes, making hypokalemia the predominant issue.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hyponatremia: While sodium levels can be affected by vomiting, hyponatremia is not the most common or significant imbalance in pyloric stenosis. The primary issue revolves around potassium and chloride.

 

Option C. Hypochloremia: Hypochloremia (low chloride levels) is indeed a significant consequence of pyloric stenosis due to the loss of hydrochloric acid in vomit. However, it is not as clinically critical as hypokalemia in this condition.

 

Option D. Hypophosphatemia: Phosphate levels are generally not significantly affected by pyloric stenosis and are not considered a major electrolyte disturbance in this context.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hypokalemia is the most common and clinically significant electrolyte imbalance seen in pyloric stenosis due to persistent vomiting and the loss of stomach acid.

questions.text: Amsel criteria is used for? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bacterial vaginosis

 

Explanation:

 

Amsel's criteria are used to diagnose bacterial vaginosis (BV). The diagnosis requires at least three out of the following four criteria to be present:

 

  1. Homogeneous, thin, white discharge that smoothly coats the vaginal walls.
  2. Clue cells on microscopy: Vaginal epithelial cells that appear stippled with bacteria.
  3. Positive whiff test: A fishy odor is released when a solution of 10% potassium hydroxide (KOH) is added to a sample of the vaginal discharge.
  4. Vaginal pH > 4.5: An elevated pH is indicative of BV.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Candidiasis: Diagnosed primarily by clinical presentation and microscopic identification of yeast cells or pseudo hyphae.

 

Option C. Cervicitis: Diagnosed based on clinical findings and specific laboratory tests for pathogens like Chlamydia trachomatis and Neisseria gonorrhoeae.

 

Option D. Trichomoniasis: Diagnosed by identifying the flagellated protozoan Trichomonas vaginalis on a wet mount microscopy or by specific antigen tests.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Amsel criteria are specifically used to diagnose bacterial vaginosis, requiring the presence of at least three out of four specific clinical and laboratory findings.

questions.text: Identify the type of placenta previa: (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Marginal

 

Given image shows a Type 2 / Marginal Placenta Previa.

 

Other Options A, C, D are explained in the table below

 

OLDER CLASSIFICATION (BROWNE’S CLASSIFICATION)

 

 

 

NEWER CLASSIFICATION (BASED ON TRANSVAGINALSONOGRAPHY)

 

  1. Placenta Previa: Placenta partially or completely covers the internal os.
  2. Low lying placenta: implantation in the lower uterine segment is such that the placental edge does not reach the internal os and remains outside a 2-cm wide perimeter around the os.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Low lying: Type 1 / Low Lying Placenta Previa is when the lower edge of the placenta enters the lower segment of the uterus but stays away from the internal os.

 

Option C. Incomplete: Type 3 / Incomplete Placenta Previa is when the placenta covers the internal os partially.

 

Option D. Complete: Type 4 / Complete Placenta Previa is when the placenta completely covers the internal os.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Marginal Placenta Previa is characterized by the placenta reaching the margin of the internal os but not covering it.

 

Ref: Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8th edition page 284, Williams textbook of Obstetrics  24th edition page 800

choices.text: Intensity is inversely proportional to squared distance
Small blood vessels are most radioresistant
Rapidly proliferating cells are most radioresistant

questions.text: A woman with endometrial carcinoma is undergoing radiotherapy. Which of the following is true? (NEET PF 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Intensity is inversely proportional to squared distance

 

Explanation

 

This statement refers to the Inverse Square Law, which states that the intensity of radiation is inversely proportional to the square of the distance from the source. This means that as the distance from the radiation source increases, the intensity of the radiation decreases exponentially. This law is fundamental in radiation physics and is crucial for understanding radiation exposure and protection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Small blood vessels are most radioresistant: This is incorrect. Larger vessels are more radioresistant compared to smaller ones. The endothelial cells lining small vessels are more susceptible to radiation damage due to their relatively higher rate of proliferation.

 

Option C. Rapidly proliferating cells are most radioresistant: This is incorrect. Rapidly proliferating cells are the most radiosensitive. Cells that are dividing quickly, such as those in the gastrointestinal tract, bone marrow, and reproductive tissues, are more susceptible to radiation damage because radiation primarily affects DNA during cell division.

 

Option D. Small bowel is most radioresistant: This is incorrect. The gastrointestinal (GI) tract, including the small bowel, is among the most radiosensitive organ systems in the body. This high radiosensitivity is due to the rapid turnover of the epithelial cells lining the GI tract.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The intensity of radiation is inversely proportional to the square of the distance from the source, as described by the Inverse Square Law.

 

Ref: Page no 610, Williams Gynecology 3rd edition

choices.text: ﻿﻿﻿For ligation of uterine artery during hysterectomy

questions.text: Identify the use of the instrument given below? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) For tubal ligation

 

Explanation:

 

  • The instrument shown is a laparoscopic ring applicator, also known as a laparocator. It is specifically designed for tubal ligation procedures. The instrument is used to apply Falope rings (silastic bands) on the fallopian tubes, which effectively block the tubes and prevent pregnancy. The Falope rings are preloaded on the tip of the instrument and are released after grasping the fallopian tube, thereby occluding the lumen.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. For ligation of uterine artery during hysterectomy: This is incorrect. The instrument shown is not used for ligating the uterine artery. Instead, instruments like clamps or ligature carriers are typically used for this purpose during a hysterectomy.

 

Option C. Ovarian cystectomy: This is incorrect. The instrument is not used for ovarian cystectomy, which involves the removal of cysts from the ovary. Instruments like scissors, graspers, and cautery devices are commonly used in ovarian cystectomy procedures.

 

Option D. Ectopic pregnancy: This is incorrect. While laparoscopic instruments are used in the surgical management of ectopic pregnancy, the specific instrument shown (laparoscopic ring applicator) is not used for this purpose. Instruments used for ectopic pregnancy surgery include laparoscopic graspers, scissors, and suction devices.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The laparoscopic ring applicator (laparocator) is used for applying Falope rings during tubal ligation procedures.

 

Ref: Page no 497, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6th edition

choices.text: Two or more iris hamartomas
Acoustic neuromas
Dysplasia of the sphenoidal and tibial bone

questions.text: Which one of the following is not included in the criteria for neurofibromatosis 1? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Acoustic neuromas 

 

In neurofibromatosis 1 (NF1), two or more of the following clinical manifestations are present:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acoustic neuromas are not a diagnostic criterion for Neurofibromatosis Type 1 (NF1); they are typically associated with Neurofibromatosis Type 2 (NF2). The diagnostic criteria for NF1 include the presence of café-au-lait macules, axillary or inguinal freckling, Lisch nodules, neurofibromas, sphenoid dysplasia, optic gliomas, and a first-degree relative with NF1.

choices.text: Bag and mask ventilation with oxygen inlet
Tubing near mouth and nose
Bag and mask ventilation without oxygen inlet

questions.text: Which of the following is not a method of administering free-flow oxygen in a neonate?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bag and mask ventilation without oxygen inlet

 

Free-flow oxygen refers to the administration of oxygen without the need for positive pressure ventilation. It is typically used to provide supplemental oxygen to neonates who are breathing spontaneously.

 

  • Bag and mask ventilation with oxygen inlet: This method allows oxygen to flow freely into the mask and can provide free-flow oxygen.
  • Face mask: Using a face mask can administer free-flow oxygen effectively.
  • Tubing near mouth and nose: Placing oxygen tubing near the mouth and nose is a common method to deliver free-flow oxygen.

 

However, bag and mask ventilation without oxygen inlet does not provide a means for oxygen to flow freely. This method relies on positive pressure ventilation, where the bag is squeezed to push air (and oxygen if connected) into the neonate's lungs, not allowing for the passive flow of oxygen.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bag and mask ventilation with oxygen inlet: This method allows oxygen to flow through the inlet, providing free-flow oxygen.

 

Option B. Face mask: A face mask can be used to deliver free-flow oxygen effectively.

 

Option C. Tubing near mouth and nose: This is a standard method for administering free-flow oxygen to neonates.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Free-flow oxygen can be administered using methods that allow passive flow of oxygen, such as a face mask or tubing near the mouth and nose. Bag and mask ventilation without an oxygen inlet does not allow for free-flow oxygen administration.

choices.text: Calcium channel blockers
Alpha methyl dopa

questions.text: A 35-year woman is a chronic hypertensive. She visits the clinic for preconception counseling. Which of the following anti-hypertensives need to be stopped prior to conception? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) ACE inhibitors

 

Explanation:

 

ACE Inhibitors in Pregnancy:

 

  • ACE inhibitors are contraindicated during pregnancy due to their association with significant fetal complications.
  • They can cause oligohydramnios, fetal growth restriction, renal dysgenesis, and even fetal death.
  • Angiotensin Receptor Blockers (ARBs) are also contraindicated for similar reasons.
  • It is essential for women on these medications to discontinue them prior to conception and switch to safer alternatives.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Calcium channel blockers: These are generally considered safe during pregnancy and do not need to be discontinued.

 

Option B. Alpha methyl dopa: This is a safe and commonly used antihypertensive during pregnancy.

 

Option D. Labetalol: Labetalol is another safe option during pregnancy and is frequently used for managing hypertension in pregnant women.

 

Educational Objective:

 

ACE inhibitors and Angiotensin Receptor Blockers are contraindicated during pregnancy and should be discontinued prior to conception.

 

Ref: Page no 401, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text:
Arrange the following steps of dilation and curettage in sequence? (INICET MAY 2022)

 

  1. Serial dilation
  2. Curettage
  3. Uterine sound
  4. Assessment of uterine size and direction
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 4-3-1-2

 

The correct sequence for performing a dilation and curettage (D&C) is as follows:

 

4. Assessment of uterine size and direction : Before any procedure, the first step is to assess the size and direction of the uterus to plan the approach and ensure that any interventions are appropriately targeted.

 

3. Uterine sound : The next step involves using a uterine sound to measure the depth and assess the shape and orientation of the uterine cavity. This helps to guide the subsequent dilation process.

 

1. Serial dilation : After assessing the uterus, serial dilation of the cervix is performed using progressively larger dilators to allow access to the uterine cavity.

 

2. Curettage : Finally, curettage is performed to remove the contents of the uterine cavity, which completes the D&C procedure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct sequence for dilation and curettage (D&C) is to first assess the uterus, perform uterine sounding, then serial dilation, and finally proceed with curettage.

 

Ref: Page no 585, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition
